content.description:
The crag's namesake is a wonderful, action packed mini pitch.  Stick clip (falling off ledges is dumb) and climb through the convoluted horizontals seeking out the well informed tic-marks.  Some long reaches lead back left across killer stone to the chains.  Embarrassingly pumpy despite its diminutive stature.

There are 3 routes serviced by 1 set of chains on the left side of the sector, this route is the one that goes right then swings back left.
7 bolts

A fun corner hand crack with poor feet. The crack is uneven in most spots, making gear placements the real crux, but the moves are quite fun for how obscure this climb is. The only reason I gave this route two stars is because of the vegetation above the roof, but once cleaned up this could make a great line.

Crack gloves come very recommended for this one.



The obvious corner hand crack about 8 meters to the right of the start of "Reclining Pine P1". The left side of the corner has almost a sort of granite feel/look to it.

Gear from BD 0.5 to 4 inches. Doubles in #1 and #2 useful.

Start as for Liquid Sky, but continue straight up.  Lots of long reaches with bad feet, featuring a crimpy crux.  Keep it together for one last lock-off to a hunky horizontal.  A great climb that is well paced.  Don't whine about it being reachy.

The directissima to the chains on the left side of the wall.
5 bolts

Starts on the same big ledge as The Search. Starts left of the arête and moves right.  Big and exposed moves gets you established on the face. Don't let your guard down because a tricky slab move guards the jugs above.  Definitely worth doing if you are in the area. 

Starts in same ledge as The Search. Climb Reclining Pine direct (10.a gear) or Youthanism (5.8) to ledge.
6 bolts

Fun climbing up a crack with a decent amount of stemming moves. Solid sustained climbing with a few good rests.



Starts from the top anchor of 'Reclining Pine Direct' or 'Reclining Pine Short'. Alternatively can be accessed by an exposed 4th class traverse.

Fixed anchors at top.

Climb the steep, tight corner using a variety of jams, jugs, and ledges. At its end, traverse a couple of feet left and overcome a roof (crux). The holds are positive, but the climbing very pumpy. Scramble up easier ground past a single bolt to a huge ledge. 
  
 From here you can either rappel, continue up a great looking 5.9 corner called Reclining Pine, or continue up a wonderful, pumpy sport route on the right called The Search.

Located on the lower tier of Liquid Sky. Look for a hand crack in a steep corner to the left of Youthanism, a 5.6 sport route.
Nuts and cams to BD #3. Doubles in hand sizes useful. There is a two bolt anchor at the top.

Climb the obvious low angle corner crack up to the lowest big ledge with a bolted chain anchor. Fun movement with good feet throughout and a roof to surmount that does go at the grade. 



The obvious low angle corner crack that goes up to the ledge system, a decent sized roof can be seen about 2/3rds height.

Standard rack, might want to double up in #2s and #3s if you're uncertain.

This is an incredible sport route that doesn't seem like it should exist in the natural world. Jugs and hand jams in horizontal cracks lead up a steep wall. 
  
 Getting to the first bolt is a bit funky, but trust me, it's worth it. Start up the corner left of the bolt (this is the beginning of the trad line called Reclining Pine). When you're level with the bolt, traverse right to reach it via a horizontal finger crack and smeary feet. A finger sized cam works well if you'd prefer to protect this bit. Alternatively, when I climbed it there was a perfect length stick on the ledge that people were obviously using as a stick clip (bring your own tape!). 
  
 After clipping the first bolt, enjoy heavenly steep and positive climbing all the way to the anchor. The hard part is choosing between jugs and bomber hand jams while trying not to get pumped out!

Located on the upper tier of Liquid Sky. To access the start, either climb Reclining Pine Direct (5.10a trad) or Reclining Pine Short (large 5.6 trad corner to the right of Reclining Pine Direct). Derek Galloway indicates in Bow Valley Sport that one can also  reach the start via an exposed 4th class traverse.
Nine bolts lead to a two bolt anchor.

Relatively straight-forward slab climbing up the side of a rock system up to a ledge (from where a number of other liquid sky routes begin)



Start at the very bottom of liquid sky wall, and follow the left side of the rock formation running parallel to the main liquid sky wall. Ends on the ledge system from which a number of other climbs on the liquid sky wall start.

Bolted
This buttress stands at the left side of the amphitheater and hosts a handful of routes on its west facing wall ranging from 5.7 to 12b
